question: 穴子
sourceMnemonic: A <kanji>hole</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> isn't some kind of creepy hole child (not sure how else to describe it). It's a <vocabulary>conger eel</vocabulary>, a type of tasty eel eaten in Japan. It might be easier to learn the reading first, though, and use that, because the second meaning option is <vocabulary>anago</vocabulary>, the Japanese word for it (also used in English).
sourceReadingMnemonic: The reading is the two kun'yomi vocab readings combined. So, <ja>穴</ja> and <ja>子</ja> to combine make <ja>あなご</ja>. Just watch out for rendaku, which changes the reading of <ja>子</ja> from <ja>こ</ja> to <ja>ご</ja>.
